option.name: title_text
option.value: Using Microsoft Outlook for Time Management

string_table.name: pxabnsnfns11111101101
string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to the training on Using Microsoft Outlook for Time Management. Click next to continue.

The purpose of this course is to provide you with the skills to effectively use Microsoft Outlook as a time management tool.

This course has audio. Please adjust your computerâ€™s speakers. If you would like to view navigation instructions for this course, click the link at the bottom of your screen.

At the completion of this lesson, you will be able to:

â€¢ Manage time effectively using Outlook calendars and tasks

â€¢ Manage email efficiently

â€¢ Use Outlook rules to prevent work interruptions

Is that what your day sounds like? Every day? Your Outlook inbox chimes as it fills to the brim with items to do. Are little pop-ups in the right, bottom corner of your screen constantly interrupting and preventing work from being done?

Is stress and chaos being created due to your email inbox being overloaded? Learn to manage your email in a way that allows you to control it, rather than allowing it to control you. Click next to learn more.

Set aside specific times during the day to look at your inbox and read emails. A best practice is to schedule approximately four times a day to check your Outlook and address your emails. Additionally, turn off your reminders in Outlook to avoid unnecessary interruptions. When executing important daily activities, it can be very tempting to glance in Outlook when emails arrive. If you close the program entirely and only open it during your chosen, allotted times, youâ€™ll find that productivity can be greatly increased.

To turn off Outlook notifications, click File, then Options in your Outlook menu. In Outlook Options, click on Mail in the menu at the left. Scroll down to the â€œMessage Arrivalâ€ section and uncheck everything in that section. This will prevent desktop alert pop-ups and distracting dings while youâ€™re working and allow you to address emails at your chosen pace.

Often it can be beneficial to allow notification sounds or desktop alerts for one or two individuals as needed to ensure you see their inquiries right away. To do so, go to File in your Outlook menu, then click the Manage Rules & Alerts button at the bottom. Set up a new rule to play a sound when you get a message from specific people, then identify that person in the Outlook address book and click the From button to identify them. Then look up and add any other individuals whose emails you need to see right away. Then choose the sound to play when you receive their emails. You may also want to set up a desktop alert to display when you receive those specific emails and click Finish once done.

Make it a rule to touch each email one time. During your specific times to address emails, read them and then determine what needs to be done with each email. You can put every email into four categories, called the 4 Ds of email:

â€¢ Do it now

â€¢ Date activate it

â€¢ Delegate it or

â€¢ Delete it

Maybe an instant reply is required and you do it now. Other emails should be filed away in an Outlook folder to be referenced at a later date. You may need to date activate it and make it a calendar or task item to be addressed later or delegated to someone else. Some emails may be strictly informational, and once youâ€™ve read the information it can be deleted.

To move an email to a folder, click the Move drop-down arrow at the top and choose what folder you want to move it to. You may also drag and drop the email to the appropriate folder on the left or right click and choose the Move option from the menu. It is a good practice to keep folders at a minimum with sensible names so you may easily find reference emails later.

The ideal situation is to touch an email once, complete whatever task it requires at that time and move on. You will begin to notice you have less emails in your inbox, and the messages you need will be easier to find.

You can also convert an email to a task. Letâ€™s look at how this is done. Click next to continue.

In Outlook, you may click on an email and drag it to Tasks in your Navigation menu at the bottom left. This will open a new window allowing you to create a new task from the email.

You may also add quick steps to the Quick Step menu to allow you to more easily move and delegate emails. Go to your Quick Step menu in your ribbon and choose Create New Step. You may name your new short cut and choose your quick step action from the drop down menu. You may add additional actions using the Add Action button. You also have the option to choose a shortcut key on your keyboard to perform this action and add a tip if you would like. Then click Finish.

To convert an email to a task to be completed later, click on or open the email in Outlook. In the Quick Steps menu, you may click Move to Tasks to create a new task using this email. A new task window will open, and you can save the information for the task and set a start date and due date. Then Outlook will remind you when the task must be completed. To see the task youâ€™ve created, you may go to your task menu by clicking tasks at the bottom left. Youâ€™ll learn more about managing tasks later in this training module.

To make an email a calendar item, first click on the email in Outlook. At the top center of your Home menu ribbon, you will see Quick Steps. Click New Meeting to create the new meeting invite using the email and your calendar. Next, a new email window will open with a calendar invite, and you can set the time and date for the meeting and add any attendees and details. Your Outlook calendar will remind you of this meeting at its scheduled time.

To see this calendar appointment, you may click calendar at the bottom left. Youâ€™ll learn more about managing your calendar later in this training module.

Use your Outlook rules to help you effortlessly manage emails. You may create new rules that send emails from individuals directly to a specific folder.

Click the drop-down arrow under Rules in your menu and choose the recipient. You will see a Rules and Alerts pop-up window. Choose the folder you want that individualâ€™s emails to automatically be redirected to. Then you may check emails from that individual at your convenience by checking that folder and keeping your Inbox clear. The folder will become bold when a new email has arrived and automatically been routed to the folder.

You may also create a new rule by clicking Rule, then Create New. The conditions for the rule will populate from the email youâ€™ve selected. If you want to create new rules and select the criteria yourself, go to File, then Manage Rules & Alerts and create the rules with your own criteria. This example shows the rule of moving messages with specific words in the subject line to a folder. Add the word to the list and click OK. Then choose the folder by clicking the hyperlinked words and select the folder already created. Click OK to implement your rule.

Think of the types of emails you receive often and from whom. Which ones can be filed away immediately to be read later? Think of the types of emails you may create rules around.

If you carry a mobile device that has work email included, it is important to remember to apply these same email practices to your mobile device. You may master your Outlook on your computer, touching emails once a day, only to have your cellular phone be a distraction.

To apply these features to a mobile device, you may go into your settings icon and click Notifications, then Mail. Then touch the green button to turn Notifications off for that mail application.
Click Next to answer the following questions to test how much youâ€™ve learned!

Always use your Outlook calendar as your primary calendar to efficiently manage your schedule. If you have to juggle a calendar on your computer, a paper calendar on your desk and an alternative calendar elsewhere, youâ€™re going to get confused and likely miss an appointment.

Your thyssenkrupp mobile device has been set up with your Outlook email; it is also synced with your Outlook calendar. Everything you need is in one place to manage your schedule and appointments.

In the main view of Outlook, you have the option to set up specific tools that will allow you to work more efficiently. You should be able to see your incoming emails and folders, but you should also have an appointment and task view set up to the right.

Any appointments scheduled on your calendar will show up to the right of your email, but you must first turn on the To-Do Bar menu. Go to your Microsoft menu and click View, then add the To-Do Bar layout. Click the drop-down menu under the To-Do Bar menu item and use the checkmarks to customize whether you want to view appointments, tasks and the month-at-a glance calendar.

Daily you may look and see what appointments are on your schedule and what tasks must be completed.

Your calendar has different views: the daily view, the work week view, the week view and the month view. You may switch between the calendars by clicking the icons in the Arrange menu in your ribbon at the top of the calendar.

Use the views that are most appropriate for the task at hand to help you stay organized.

You also have the option to go directly into your calendar and create new appointments.

Click on Calendar in your Navigation pane at the bottom left, select the date and time you would like to schedule an appointment and click New Appointment. Once in the appointment you may include a subject and location, start times and end times and invite attendees. You may click on the Scheduling Assistant to view the schedules of those youâ€™ve invited to ensure your meeting does not conflict with other appointments. Be sure to hit Send when once your meeting invitation is complete.

If you do not have the Navigation pane menu at the bottom left, go to View and click Navigation Pane and select Normal.

You may move emails to your calendar as an attachment. It can be helpful to have the original email saved in the calendar appointment for future reference.

To do so, go to your Quick Step menu and click Create New. Name the action Move to Calendar or something similar that will allow you to remember the action. Then use the Choose an Action drop-down menu to choose the option Create an appointment with an attachment.

This feature will move the selected email to the calendar appointment as an attachment.

Outlook offers the sharing of calendars. This feature allows others to view your calendar for more efficient scheduling. For example, your direct manager or team may ask you to share your calendars to prevent infringing upon other meetings or appointments you have scheduled.

To share your calendar, go to the Calendar view of Outlook and click Share Calendar in your menu ribbon at the top. An email that looks like a sharing invitation will open, and you may enter the individual you would like to share your calendar with and type any appropriate message explaining the sharing request.

Click Send to send the sharing invitation.
Click Next to answer the following questions to test how much youâ€™ve learned!

In this course, you learned how to:

Manage time effectively using Outlook calendars and tasks

Manage email efficiently

Use Outlook rules to prevent work interruptions

Letâ€™s see what youâ€™ve learned!

Answer the following questions in the graded final quiz. 80 % is a passing score.

A Quick Reference Guide for Using Outlook for Time Management is available in the Resources section of this training.

Click Resources in the top right of this module if you would like to print the guide.

Let us know what you think! Please take the survey through we.learn to give us feedback. Your input is valuable to us.

To close this course, click the â€œXâ€ to close the window.

In the earlier lesson, you saw how to convert an email to a task for yourself. Often it may be necessary to delegate a task to another individual and assign it to them for completion.

When delegating tasks to others, always remember:

Plan before you delegate- think of how the team can contribute to finishing the job

Determine who to assign the task to-choose the best person and donâ€™t delegate unless itâ€™s efficient. Delegating is not about passing the buck!

Communicate, communicate, communicate- do not just task someone with an assignment without them agreeing to it first.

Then create the task assignment in Outlook and

Follow up

Click next to learn more about these steps.

To assign a task in Outlook, go to the Task view by clicking Task in your Navigation Pane menu at the bottom left. Click New Task to open and name the task with an appropriate subject that both you and your delegate will understand. Enter appropriate start dates and due dates and set a priority.

Communicate in the message box appropriate information the delegate should know in order to complete the task. Then click Assign Task in the menu ribbon at the top and type the name of the delegate in the To line. Once your task assignment is complete, click Send.

You may also delegate a task using email. First, communicate with the delegate requesting their assistance with a task. Generate the task by going to your Sent items and right click to access the Quick Step menu, then select create a task with an attachment and assign it to the delegate.
